## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been playing around with VerusIDs and I noticed something interesting. Can you explain why I can create a currency from an ID with a properly encoded i-address as its actual name?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, you can't. The protocol advises against creating an ID with an i-address as its name, as it will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used. This is because an i-address will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity that has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. It's not recommended to use an i-address as an ID name.

**User:**
Okay, that makes sense. I was also wondering, is it possible to create a PBaaS chain with the same name as a currency already supported in the Verus Desktop, such as BTC or ETH?

**AI Assistant:**
No, it's not possible. The Verus Desktop has a limitation in this testnet release that prevents you from using the same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation will be resolved before mainnet availability.

**User:**
Got it, thanks for the clarification. One more question: is this software considered stable and fully tested?

**AI Assistant:**
No, it's not. The software is explicitly labeled as "experimental and unfinished" and comes with a disclaimer that it should be used at your own risk, with no warranty for any kind of damage. So, please be careful when using it and keep in mind that it's still a work in progress.
Can you explain why I can create a currency from an ID with a properly encoded i-address as its actual name?

Actually, you can't. The protocol advises against creating an ID with an i-address as its name, as it will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used. This is because an i-address will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity that has that i-address calculated based on its name registration.

#### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of:
1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.2. (GUI) If a currency is supported in the Verus Desktop already, such as BTC or ETH, you will not be able to use those same named currencies as a PBaaS chain. This limitation is considered errata for this testnet release and will not be a limitation before mainnet availability.### DisclaimerThis is experimental and unfinished software. Use at your own risk! No warranty for any kind of damage!
